III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff responsibilities.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The foster care worker allowed the relative to transport the toddler
foster child without a proper car seat or booster seat.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Parent 1: On 7/18/2024 I interviewed Foster Parent 1 by
telephone. Foster Parent 1 confirmed the information stated in the
complaint. She reported, Child A (age 4) and Child B(age2) whom
she and her husband, Foster Parent 2, had fostered since
9/11/2020 and 12/1/2021 respectively were recently replaced from
their foster home. She reported following a Family Team Meeting
(FTM) on 7/12/2024 they were allowed a goodbye visit with the
boys on 7/16/2024. Foster Parent 1 said they met Foster Care
Worker (FCW) and the relative caregiver at a park for the goodbye
visit. When it was time for the children to leave, Foster Parent 2
went to buckle Child A into the relative caregiver’s car and noticed
there was no car seat or booster seat. Foster Parent 2 advised
FCW of this. FCW rolled her eyes and said okay. FCW did not go
check the relative caregiver’s car. FCW let the relative caregiver
leave. Foster Parent 1 reported concern about the car/booster
seat because of the law, and what she thought was a lack of
concern for its absence by FCW.
Chief Administrator: I spoke with Chief Administrator (CA) about
this allegation by telephone on 7/19/2024. CA reported not being
present on the day of the incident. She reported FCW completed a
safety plan with Relative Caregiver that Relative Caregiver cannot
transport without a proper safety seat. CA reported Relative
2

Caregiver sent a picture showing that she had the car seats. CA
advised that Relative Caregiver had car seats prior to this incident
as it was documented in Relative Caregiver’s 3130A Assessment,
which was completed prior to the children’s goodbye visit at the
park. CA was not sure why Relative Caregiver did not have the
car seat with her at the park to transport Child A.
Foster Care Worker: On 7/25/2024 I interviewed Foster Care
Worker (FCW) by telephone. FCW denied rolling her eyes as
reported by Foster Parent 1 but did not deny the allegation. She
explained the situation. She reported when the foster parents told
her there was no car seat for Child A, she did not know where to
get a car seat in the moment, and given that she does not have
children, she did not know it was not appropriate for Relative
Caregiver to transport Child A without a car or booster seat. She
said because of her not knowing this she reached out to her
supervisor during the situation by text, and later by telephone. Her
supervisor advised her that since Child A was only four years old,
Child A should be in a car seat. FCW reported Relative Caregiver
had pulled away prior to her contact with her supervisor. FCW
admitted she did not problem solve the situation in the moment.
She “took it as make sure they do not do it again” so she
completed a safety plan with the relative caregiver on 7/17/2024.
She also verified that Relative Caregiver had a car and booster
seat. Relative Caregiver reported she had the car seat but since
she came to the park with four of her five children in the car, she
did not bring it as there was not room. FCW said she also
completed a car seat training with Relative Caregiver on
7/24/2024. FCW reported Relative Caregiver has since
purchased a van to be able to safely transport all the children.
Supervisor: On 9/6/2024 I made a follow up telephone contact to
the agency at which time I interviewed Supervisor. Supervisor
confirmed information as reported by CA and FCW related to the
situation at the park, and Relative Caregiver reporting to have car
seats prior to the children’s placement with her. Supervisor
clarified that when FCW called her from the park, she did not
know if Relative Caregiver was still at the park. She advised FCW
to go verify what the foster parents reported about no car seat for
Child A, and that’s when FCW said Relative Caregiver had left. At
that point Supervisor advised FCW to develop a safety plan with
Relative Caregiver, which FCW completed. Supervisor reported
the agency does have car seats at the agency which can be used
in emergency situations/when needed.
Document Review:
3

• Initial Relative Placement Home Study-3130A dated
7/3/2024 which indicated Relative Caregiver had access to
required safe seats for transportation.
• Copy of a 7/17/2024, email to Relative Caregiver from FCW
outlining a safety plan which indicated: Relative Caregiver
will ensure Child A and Child B ride in a child safe car seat
while in a vehicle, being transported, and that the children
will be buckled in before the vehicle drives away.
Additionally, that Relative Caregiver will contact Ennis for
assistance with car seat installation if needed and will
reference the car seat manual to ensure the car seats are
being used appropriately and the children fit their seats
correctly.
• Copy of a 7/17/2024 email reply from Relative Caregiver to
FCW regarding the safety plan that indicated Relative
Caregiver had read everything and agrees to the terms of
the safety plan.
• A signed statement by Relative Caregiver dated 7/24/2024
showing she received car seat training.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed there is evidence
the worker was unable to problem solve the situation completely in
the moment, but safety planned with Relative Caregiver shortly
after the incident. Her actions related to this safety planning
demonstrated the agency’s efforts to directly work with the child,
the child’s family and others related to the case service plan.
Technical assistance
The worker asking the relative caregiver to wait, not drive off while
the worker had direct contact with her supervisor to problem solve
this matter in the moment was advisable. It is recommended that
the agency provide additional instructions to workers around how
to enhance problem solving in urgent situations.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code Change of placement.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12405
Section (3) The agency shall document all the following in the child's
Description record before a change of placement occurs:
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of the
following:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the change,
except when prior notification would jeopardize the child’s care or
4

safety. If prior notice is not provided, then the agency shall notify
the foster parent, at the time of the change, why prior notice was
not given.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency replaced the children without providing written notice
to the foster parents.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Parent 1: On 7/18/2024 I interviewed Foster Parent 1 by
telephone. Foster Parent 1 reported Child A and Child B were
removed from her and her husband’s care without proper
notification. Foster Parent 1 reported they knew the children were
going to be moved; that there was a 7/12/2024 FTM where it was
discussed. She reported this was not a court ordered move, but
one that was at the agency’s discretion. She said the Children’s
GAL (Guardian Ad Litem), Child A's therapist and the biological
parent were not supportive of the move given that permanent
custody was being pursued and the length of time Child A and
Child B had been in the home. Notwithstanding that, there was to
be a transition to take place related to the move that was to occur.
The children were to visit with Relative Caregiver on 7/14/2024
and return to their foster home on 7/16/2024. An official move date
was set for 7/18/2024. Then the move was changed to 7/16/2024.
Foster Parent 1 reported they did not appeal to the foster care
review board or ask for a meeting with the agency director about
their placement change concerns. They did not because the
worker and licensing supervisor explained the change of
placement was at the agency’s discretion and the agency director
was at the FTM. Foster Parent 1 reported they never received a
written notice related to the replacement move.
Chief Administrator: I spoke with Chief Administrator (CA) about
this allegation by telephone on 7/19/2024. CA affirmed Foster
Parent 1’s reporting related to the FTM date, discussion about
replacement, and the visitation time frame for returning to the
foster home on 7/16/2024. She reported the FTM was the foster
parent’s opportunity to mention concerns about the replacement,
but the foster parents did not. The foster parent brought up other
concerns about the children being in Relative Caregiver’s care
which were addressed.
CA reported the replacement move timeframe changed because
of the outcome of their agency’s licensing department’s special
evaluation on Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2. There had
been allegations of maltreatment of the children by the foster
5

parents, and on 7/15/2024, the allegations were substantiated.
Revocation of Foster Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s foster home
license was the agency’s recommendation and based on that
recommendation, the agency determined returning the children to
Foster Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s care would not be
appropriate. CA reported the agency attempted a special
evaluation preliminary findings summary with the foster parents on
7/12/2024, but the foster parents did not answer. The worker
advised the foster parents of the agency’s special evaluation
findings and recommendation on 7/15/2023. The foster parents
were provided the DHS-30 via email on 7/15/2024.
Foster Care Worker: On 7/25/2024 I interviewed Foster Care
Worker (FCW) by telephone. FCW reported a relative placement
was already in progress prior to a complaint coming forth related
to Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2. Relative Caregiver was
identified in early June 2024. FCW informed Foster Parent 1 and
Foster Parent 2 of her search for relative caregivers for the
children and she kept them informed of the progress of her
relative searches at each foster home visit, and at court hearings
which Foster Parent 1 attended. FCW reported following the
agency’s decision to move forward with Relative Caregiver for
placement of the children, an FTM was held on 7/12/2024 to
discuss the replacement plans. FCW affirmed CA’s reporting
related to the foster parent’s attending the FTM. FCW reported
Child A’s and Child B’s replacement move was to be gradual. The
boys were visiting with Relative Caregiver with a plan to return to
the foster home prior to an official move date, but after foster care
received the outcome of a special evaluation on Foster Parent 1
and Foster Parent 2 on 7/15/2024 with the recommendation of
revocation, the children’s replacement date was moved up to
7/15/2024. FCW called Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 on
7/15/2024 and informed them that the children would be officially
placed with Relative Caregiver and would not be returning to
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 from the visit with Relative
Caregiver. The foster parents did not think the children should be
moved, but at that time they did not ask for an exact reason for the
move. FCW said the foster parents knew that the visit on
7/16/2024 was to be a goodbye visit. On 7/15/2024 FCW emailed
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 the DHS-30-Foster
Parent/Caregiver Notice of Move for Child A and Child B. FCW
provided me a copy of each child’s DHS-30 and an email showing
the certified mail notice receipt for what FCW said was her mailing
the DHS-30 to Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2.
6

Supervisor: On 9/6/2024 I made a follow up telephone contact to
the agency at which time I interviewed Supervisor. Supervisor
affirmed information as reported by CA and FCW related Child A
and Child B’s replacement and the agency contact and notification
to Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 related to the children’s
replacement.
Document Review.
Child A’s and Child B’s MISACWIS case file which showed:
• Child A and Child B are temporary court wards.
• Child A was originally placed with Foster Parent 1 and
Foster Parent 2 on 9/11/2020; and Child B was originally
placed with them on 12/1/2021.
• Both children were replacement from Foster Parent 1’s and
Foster Parent 2’s home on 3/30/2023 and then returned to
their care on 4/21/2023 until 7/15/2023.
• Child A and Child B were placed with Relative Caregiver on
7/15/2024.
Copy of a DHS-30 for Child A and Child B dated 7/15/2024:
• Was addressed to Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2.
• Advised these foster parents the department has reason to
believe the child has suffered sexual maltreatment or non-
accidental physical injury or there is a substantial risk of
harm to the child’s well-being.
• Advised these foster parents that they can appeal the
respective child’s move to the foster care review board.
Email from FCW which attached a certified mail receipt that was
addressed to Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 from when
FCW reported sending the DHS-30 to the foster parents by mail.
Copy of a special evaluation report for Foster Parent 1 and Foster
Parent 2 dated 7/15/202 which showed:
• A special evaluation intake allegation of sexual and
physical maltreatment; alleging the foster father bathed or
showered with Child A, the foster parents use corporal
punishment, and that the foster parents are not providing
proper care for the children in the home.
• The special evaluation found the foster home in violation of
the allegations and revocation of the foster parents’ foster
home license was recommended.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence does
not support the allegations or that the foster parents were not
given written notice of the children’s move and reason for the
move.
7

Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child, and
Description the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's placement at least
once every month.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The foster care worker did not make a monthly visit to the foster
home for the month of July 2024.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Parent 1: On 7/18/2024 I interviewed Foster Parent 1 by
telephone. Foster Parent 1 reported FCW did not make a July
2024 monthly foster home visit. She said on 7/3/2024 she asked
for a foster home visit and FCW said they would schedule a home
visit. Foster Parent 1 said she texted FCW her availability on
7/10/2024, but a foster home visit never occurred. Foster Parent
1 admitted Child A and Child B were visiting Relative Caregiver in
July and were replaced from their foster home on 7/15/2024.
Chief Administrator, FCW and Supervisor. I interviewed each
staff person separately by telephone on 7/19/2024, 7/25/2024,
and 9/6/2024 respectively. Each of them denied the allegation.
FCW reported there was no home visit with Foster Parent 1 and
Foster Parent 2 in July due to Child A and Child B’s replacement
on 7/15/2024. FCW as well as CA and Supervisor reported FCW
had a monthly home visit with Child A, and Child B in their
placement with Relative Caregiver that complied with rule and
policy related to the worker’s monthly visitation with the respective
child and their caregiver.
Document Review:
Child A’s and Child B’s MISAWIS case file which showed:
• A 7/16/2024 social work contact for a home visit that
documented a home visit with Child A, Child B and
Relative Caregiver on that date.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed, the evidence does
not support the allegation or a missed monthly home visit by the
worker with the child and the child’s caregiver.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
The agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing rules and statutes.
